Paediatric anaesthetic guideline / 13006 / 3.0
Page  of
Introduction
To give clear direction on the hospital's position concerning elective and emergency anaesthesia for children.

This protocol covers the majority of cases and situations; however there may be exceptional circumstances that require consultants to make informed decisions balancing the risk and benefit of proceeding outside of this guideline. Where these situations arise there must be clear documentation about the discussions that took place between professionals and with the child and family.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individual (Refer to appendix 3)
Scope
(Refer to Appendix 1: Criteria for referral for physician led pre-assessment for children scheduled for surgery)
This policy applies to all surgeons and anaesthetic staff providing surgery and anaesthesia to children and young people up to 16 years old.

The minimum age limit for administration of anaesthesia for elective procedures at Broomfield Hospital is 3 months for term infants (55 weeks post-menstrual age). This will often need to be adjusted for ex-premature infants and also depends on associated co-morbidities.

Generally all consultant level anaesthetists at Broomfield Hospital are competent to anaesthetise ASA 1 or 2 children at ages over 3 years for non-complex elective procedures. There  are a smaller number of consultants with experience and extra training in paediatric anaesthesia who are competent to anaesthetise younger age groups with more complex needs. Planning of procedures is particularly important in these children to ensure adequately experienced staff are available.

There may be some children who do not fit the criteria for surgery and anaesthesia at Broomfield Hospital due to age, associated co-morbidities or surgical complexity. These children will need safe transfer to a suitable paediatric centre (refer to the Transferring children guideline). If the condition is not urgent, a routine tertiary referral should be made.

Wherever possible, Procedures involving general anaesthesia in children should take  place within “daytime working hours” in order to maximise availability of support. Procedures in children outside these times should be made on a case by case basis involving senior clinicians and should take into account the urgency of the procedure and the risk of anaesthesia.
Definitions

table_items.text: ASA is a physiological status classification used to assess fitness of patients for surgery: ASA 1 is a healthy patient, ASA 2 has mild systemic disease
ASA 3 is a patient with severe systemic disease

data.text: Supervision of non-consultant anaesthetic staff and trainees by
consultant anaesthetists

The responsible consultant must be made aware of planned procedures in ALL CHILDREN < 16 years of age. It is the responsibility of the consultant to assess the level of supervision required taking into account the level of training of the attending anaesthetist.

If deemed appropriate, Children over 5 years (ASA 1&2) may be anaesthetised for non-complex procedures by a trainee with intermediate paediatric anaesthesia training, or NCCG with relevant experience under distant consultant supervision. Attending anaesthetists without intermediate training should have local or immediate supervision, dependent on their experience.

If deemed appropriate, Children between 3-5 years (ASA 1&2) may be  anaesthetised for non-complex procedures by a trainee with higher paediatric anaesthesia training or NCCG with relevant experience under distant consultant supervision.

Children under 3 years, ASA 3 and above or undergoing complex procedures should ordinarily have immediate consultant supervision unless this has been agreed by the supervising consultant and the attending anaesthetist holds advanced paediatric anaesthesia training or relevant experience.
Pre-assessment for elective procedures in children
All children having elective procedures involving anaesthesia in Broomfield Hospital should undergo either nurse led or physician led pre-assessment (refer to Appendix 1 for non-COVID time pathway)
Elective surgery and general anaesthesia for imaging
Children admitted for planned procedures should be scheduled on weekday elective lists (Monday to Friday) during the daytime in order to maximise availability of support staff.

Wizard ward currently does not admit children on evening 3rd session or at the weekend. Elective procedures during these times are possible only on a case by case basis by prior arrangement, taking into account competency clinical staff, availability of support staff and ward bed.
Emergency surgery
Any child requiring emergency surgery “out of hours” (outside Monday to Friday 08:00-20:00) should be discussed with the consultant surgeon and consultant anaesthetist on call.
There is specific consultant cover for children requiring surgery for plastic and orthopaedic trauma on Saturday / Sunday and bank holidays between 08:00 & 18:00.
Children under the age of 3 should only be considered for anaesthesia outside normal working hours for life and limb or sight saving surgery. This reflects
the balance of risk over benefit to the child. Factors such as the child's age, co-morbidities and  starvation time will need to be discussed between the consultant anaesthetist and surgeon on call.
Children over 3 years of age are appropriate for emergency anaesthesia before
hrs. After 22.00 hrs only life and limb saving surgery should be contemplated, this reflects the same guidance applied to adult patients.
Children deferred during out of hours are to be given priority on the emergency list or the start of an elective list the following day.
Arrangement for paediatric elective surgery in the covid era
Children requiring elective surgery / procedure under anaesthesia will need to follow the pathway set out in Appendix 2.
Cleft palate emergency surgery

Infants and children requiring surgery for cleft lip and palate who require emergency surgery following planned surgery may occasionally need to return to theatre due to post-operative complications. Arrangements are in place within the anaesthetic department for the care of cleft surgery patients to be operated on out of hours by a consultant anaesthetist who has regular experience of cleft anaesthesia.
Paediatric breathing systems

Paediatric circle breathing systems can be used for multiple patients, provided that a new single use HME filter is used for each patient. The circle system should be changed if they become visibly contaminated or if there is evidence of infection with respiratory viruses, including Covid-19. They should also be changed once the theatre session has finished, or at the end of the day for a full day list.
The same applies to the Jackson-Rees modification of the Ayre's T-piece breathing system.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Safe Paediatric Surgery Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Safe Paediatric Surgery Group and appropriate staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
All anaesthesia and surgical trainees to be informed of this policy on induction.  Audit and monitoring
All breaches of this guideline must be reported on a risk event form.
All incidents relating to this guideline will be investigated, an action plan drawn up and recommendations made for improving care provided.
There will be an annual audit of children undergoing anaesthetic, which will be presented on the joint paediatric/ anaesthetic annual audit.
This guideline will be monitored by the Safe Paediatric Surgery group.
References
NCEPOD, (2011). Surgery in children: are we there yet? London:NCEPOD. Available at: www.ncepod.org.uk/2011sic.html

Royal College of Anaesthetists, (2020). Guidelines for the provision of anaesthetic services: chapter 10 Guidelines for the provision of paediatric anaesthesia services. London:RCOA. Available at: www.rcoa.ac.uk/gpas
RCPCH, (2021). National guidance for the recovery of elective surgery in children. London:RCPCH.Available at: www.rcpch.ac.uk/resources/national-guidance- recovery-elective-surgery-children
APA Paediatric Breathing Circuit Questionnaire (2015) APA Statement (2005)
Appendix : Criteria for referral for physician led pre-assessment for children scheduled for surgery
All primary cleft children should have already been pre-assessed by an anaesthetist i.e. those children having cleft lip or palate repair as infants
Other children who should be referred for anaesthetic pre-assessment if they have not already been seen by an anaesthetist are:
Ex-prem infants and children - >6 weeks premature and/or IPPV
Any syndromic children
Any previous anaesthetic difficulty
A strong family history of anaesthetic related problems (Malignant hyperpyrexia / suxamethonium apnoea)
Any known airway problems including obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA)
Any children significantly underweight (<5th percentile or acute drop)
Any children who are significantly obese (>95th percentile for age and gender)
Any significant coexisting disease e.g. severe or poorly controlled asthma, diabetes, poorly controlled epilepsy, cardiac conditions, myopathy, chronic lung disease, ASA 3 or above)
Children with URTI if surgery is planned within the next 2 weeks
Surgery >2 hours or complicated surgery
A child with autism or moderate / severe preoperative anxiety to formulate a plan
We do not have a Paediatric HDU at Broomfield Hospital thus Children at risk from respiratory complications unsuitable for DGH adenotonsillectomy at Broomfield Hospital:
Age <2 years
Weight <15kg
Failure to thrive (weight <5th percentile for age)
Obesity (BMI >2.5SDS or >99th percentile for age and gender)
Severe cerebral palsy
Hypotonia or neuromuscular disorders (moderate or severely affected)
Significant craniofacial anomalies
Mucopolysaccharidoses and syndromes associated with difficult airway
Significant comorbidity (e.g. congenital heart disease, chronic lung disease. ASA 3 or above)
ECG or echocardiographic abnormalities
Severe OSA (PSG indices: AHI >10, Respiratory Disturbance Index >40, and Oxygen saturation nadir <80%)
Also if the parents have specific concerns they wish to discuss with an anaesthetist please contact one of us.
To refer a child or discuss with an anaesthetist, please contact Preassessment uni

table_items.text: INITIAL PRE-ASSESSMENT (IDEALLY VIRTUAL) AT LEAST 2 WEEKS PRIOR TO PROCEDURE FOR OPERATIVE CATEGORY 2 & ABOVE. CARERS SHOULD HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO DISCUSS ADMISSION & PROCEDURES- IT SHOULD BE EXPLAINED THAT THERE IS A SMALL CHANCE OF CHILD / RESIDENT CARER ACQUIRING COVID-19 DURING ADMISSION, THOUGH THIS IS UNLIKELY TO AFFECT THE CHILD'S SURGICAL COURSE. THIS SHOULD BE RECORDED AS PART OF CONSENT WHEREVER POSSIBLE.
STANDARD SOCIAL DISTANCING PRACTICE FOR CHILD AND HOUSEHOLD PRIOR TO SURGERY. HOUSEHOLD OR PATIENT ISOLATION NOT REQUIRED UNLESS REQUESTED BY CLINICAL TEAM AT TIME OF PREASSESSMENT
FURTHER SYMPTOM CHECK ASSESSMENT OF CHILD & HOUSEHOLD (CALL/ VIRTUAL) NO MORE THAN 72 HOURS PRIOR TO SURGERY - IF ANYONE IN THE HOUSEHOLD HAS “RED FLAG”
SYMPTOMS** OR HAS A POSITIVE COVID SWAB WITHIN 2 WEEKS OF SURGERY, CANCEL OPERATION UNLESS URGENT (RISK vs BENEFIT DISCUSSION REQUIRED). RESCHEDULE AT LEAST 2 WEEKS PENDING REASSESSMENT & SWABBING

ONE CARER TO ATTEND / STAY WITH CHILD FOR DAY-CASE. FOR INPATIENTS, SWAPPING OF A SINGLE CARER FROM THE SAME HOUSEHOLD IS PERMISSIBLE. WHEN AWAY FROM BEDSIDE, CARER SHOULD WEAR DROPLET PROTECTION MASK & REFRAIN FROM VISITING COVID RISK AREAS.

data.text: WARD PPE    STAFF, CHILD (IF POSSIBLE) & PARENT TO WEAR DROPLET PROTECTION (STANDARD
SURGICAL FACE-MASK) WHILST IN HOSPITAL.
ELECTIVE CASES TO BE ADMITTED TO A PAEDIATRIC COMPLIANT “CLEAN” AREA (i.e. NOT IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY OF MEDICALLY UNWELL, CHILDREN WITH “RED FLAG”
WARD  SYMPTOMS), THOUGH THEY CAN BE ADMITTED TO AN AREA WHERE OTHERWISE WELL FACILITIES   CHILDREN ARE AWAITING SWAB RESULTS PRIOR TO THEIR SURGERY.
IN THE ELECTIVE SITUATION, SIDE ROOMS SHOULD BE PRIORITISED FOR THOSE PATIENTS/CARERS WHO ARE SHIELDING.
USE FOR INDUCTION UNLESS CONFIRMED COVID-19 (USE THEATRE IN THIS CASE).
ANAESTHETIC    PPE AS PER PHE GUIDANCE FOR ANAESTHETIC STAFF
ROOM     PARENT & ACCOMPANYING NURSE/PLAY SPECIALIST TO WEAR DROPLET
PROTECTION (STANDARD MASK) FOR INDUCTION AND LEAVE PRIOR TO AEROSOL GENERATING PROCEDURE.
SURGICAL & SCRUB STAFF CAN WEAR STANDARD DROPLET PROTECTION PPE UNLESS PATIENT UNDERGOING AGP AS PART OF THEIR SURGICAL PROCEDURE IN A COVID POSITIVE, SUSPECTED OR UNKNOWN PATIENT.
THEATRE     AGPs, SUCH AS ENDOTRACHEAL EXTUBATION SHOULD BE DONE IN THEATRE IF
POSSIBLE WITH A MINIMUM NUMBER OF KEY STAFF PRESENT TO ENSURE SAFETY- ALL STAFF PRESENT MUST WEAR AEROSOL PROTECTION PPE
AT THE TIME AND IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING EXTUBATION, IF THE PATIENT IS COVID SUSPECTED, POSITIVE OR UNKNOWN. PATIENT CAN BE TAKEN TO RECOVERY AS SOON
AS SAFE.

A MINIMUM TIME OF 5 AIR-CHANGES POST AGP SHOULD ELAPSE BEFORE THEATRE STAFF CAN RE-ENTER THEATRE WEARING DROPLET PROTECTION PPE- (USUALLY 20 MINS OR 5 MINS FOR A LAMINAR FLOW THEATRE) IF THE PATIENT IS COVID POSITIVE, SUSPECTED OR UNKNOWN.
SEPARATE “HOT” AND “COLD” CHILDREN'S RECOVERY NOT REQUIRED
LMA CAN BE REMOVED WITH IMMEDIATE ATTENDING RECOVERY STAFF
RECOVERY   WEARING FULL AEROSOL PROTECTION PPE & 2 METER SPACING BETWEEN
PATIENTS IF PATIENT IS COVID POSITIVE, SUSPECTED OR UNKNOWN.
OPA (GUIDEL) - CAN BE REMOVED WITH ATTENDING RECOVERY STAFF
WEARING STANDARD DROPLET PPE.
POST-    FOLLOWING SURGERY, CHILDREN SHOULD BE DISCHARGED FROM HOSPITAL AS OPERATIVE  RAPIDLY AS POSSIBLE.
WARD    UNPLANNED ADMISSIONS FOLLOWING DAY-CASES / RE-ADMISSIONS SHOULD BE INTO MANAGEMENT  A PAEDIATRIC COMPLIANT “CLEAN” AREA (e.g. SIDE ROOM ON PAEDIATRIC WARD)
POST-OP    CHILDREN AND RESIDENT CARERS DO NOT NEED TO ROUTINELY SELF ISOLATE AFTER
DISCHARGE UNLESS DIAGNOSED WITH COVID-19 OR REQUESTED TO BY THEIR CLINICAL ISOLATION  TEAM
COVID-19 RED FLAG SIGNS & SYMPTOMS  PYREXIA > 37.6 degrees
NEW COUGH
NEW CORYZAL SYMPTOMS
NEW LETHARGY
NEW SHORTNESS OF BREATH
RCS - SURGICAL PRIORITY CATEGORIES
CAT 1a   EMERGENCY- OPERATION REQUIRED WITHIN 24 HOURS  CAT 1b   URGENT- OPERATION NEEDED WITHIN 72 HOURS
CAT 2   SURGERY THAT CAN BE DEFERRED FOR UP TO 4 WEEKS  CAT 3   SURGERY THAT CAN BE DELAYED FOR UP TO 3 MONTHS
